name: (2E)-2-benzyl-3-phenylprop-2-enoic anhydride
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1366
Reason: The compound (2E)-2-benzyl-3-phenylprop-2-enoic anhydride is a complex molecule featuring an anhydride group and three benzyl substituents linked to an alkene chain. Benzoic anhydride, as a reference compound, has a melting point of approximately 42°C. Each benzyl group can increase the melting point by about 5-10°C due to steric hindrance and increased molecular weight. The anhydride group typically contributes more significantly to the melting point, increasing it by around 20-30°C due to the possibility of intermolecular hydrogen bonding and the rigid structure it imparts to the compound. However, careful analysis is required as substituents can have non-additive effects. Given the substituents present in the compound, we consider the following approximate increases to the melting point: - Anhydride group: +20-30°C - Each benzyl group: +5-10°C Since there are three benzyl groups, their combined contribution would be between 15-30°C.
